importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The article was published on October 17, 2025, marking a recent spike in global interest in Hussar jackets, as noted by a 300% increase in searches for the term during October 2025.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The fashion trend of wearing military-style Hussar jackets began in the 1960s with Jimi Hendrix, reached mainstream popularity in 2005 with Kate Moss at Glastonbury, and has seen a resurgence in recent years.

keyTakeAways: Military-style Hussar jackets, historically associated with 18th-century European military uniforms, are experiencing a significant revival in contemporary fashion.
Celebrities like Jodie Turner-Smith, Zendaya, Jenna Ortega, and Jimi Hendrix have helped popularize the style, often through subversive or artistic reinterpretations.
The trend originated with anti-establishment movements, such as The Beatles' 1967 'Sgt. Pepper' album cover, which used military coats to convey peace and rebellion.
Modern luxury fashion brands like Saint Laurent, Gucci, Marc Jacobs, and Dior have reimagined the Hussar jacket with elaborate detailing and avant-garde styling.
A 300% increase in global searches for 'Hussar jacket' in October 2025 indicates a major shift in consumer interest and public attention to the style.

namedEntities.name: Jodie Turner-Smith
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is featured as a prominent figure who wore a military-style Hussar jacket at a Victoria's Secret after-party, symbolizing the current resurgence of the style in high fashion.

namedEntities.name: Zendaya
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She was spotted wearing a military-style dress-coat at a Louis Vuitton show, linking the trend to 18th-century French royal fashion and anti-establishment aesthetics.

namedEntities.name: Jenna Ortega
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She was seen wearing a gothic black Hussar vest at a Dior show, showcasing the continued use of military-inspired outerwear in modern fashion events.

namedEntities.name: Jimi Hendrix
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He popularized the use of Hussar jackets in the 1960s through a subversive, bohemian style, influencing later fashion trends and inspiring modern reinterpretations.

namedEntities.name: The Beatles
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They used military coats on the cover of 'Sgt. Pepper' to convey anti-establishment and anti-war sentiments, marking one of the first major cultural uses of the style in fashion.

namedEntities.name: Kate Moss
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She helped mainstream the trend in 2005 by wearing a Hussar jacket to Glastonbury, bringing the style into wider public consciousness.

namedEntities.name: Keburia
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: A Georgian-based brand that sold the Hussar jacket worn by Jodie Turner-Smith, representing the modern availability and commercialization of the style.

namedEntities.name: Saint Laurent
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Reimagined the Hussar jacket with elaborate detailing and modern styling, contributing to the trend's evolution in luxury fashion.

namedEntities.name: Gucci
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Included military-style Hussar jackets in its collections, helping to popularize the style among high-end fashion consumers.

namedEntities.name: Marc Jacobs
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Presented a cream wool Hussar jacket in 2002 with gold stitching, echoing Jimi Hendrix’s style and influencing modern interpretations.

namedEntities.name: Dior
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Featured Hussar jackets in Jonathan Anderson’s debut menswear collection, indicating the style’s continued presence on fashion catwalks.

namedEntities.name: McQueen
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Included military-inspired outerwear in recent collections, aligning with the broader revival of the Hussar jacket trend.

namedEntities.name: Vaquera
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Included the Hussar jacket in recent collections, contributing to the style’s presence in modern fashion.

namedEntities.name: Ann Demeulemeester
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Featured the Hussar jacket in recent collections, reinforcing its role in avant-garde fashion.

namedEntities.name: Molly Rooyakkers
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Fashion analyst and social media influencer
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Runs the fashion analytics account @styleanalytics and reported a 300% increase in global searches for 'Hussar jacket' in October 2025, indicating growing public interest.

namedEntities.name: Victoria’s Secret
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Serves as a venue where fashion trends are showcased, such as at the after-party where Jodie Turner-Smith wore a Hussar jacket.

namedEntities.name: Louis Vuitton
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hosted a fashion show where Zendaya wore a military-style dress-coat, linking the trend to high-profile fashion events.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The military-style Hussar jacket, historically tied to 18th-century military uniforms, is experiencing a major fashion resurgence. Celebrities like Jodie Turner-Smith, Zendaya, and Jenna Ortega have been spotted wearing these jackets in high-profile events, blending historical elements with modern, often subversive interpretations. The trend began in the 1960s with Jimi Hendrix and The Beatles, who used the coats as symbols of rebellion and anti-establishment ideals. Since then, it gained traction through musicians like Kate Moss and artists in the 2000s, and is now being reimagined by luxury fashion houses such as Saint Laurent, Gucci, and Dior. A sharp 300% increase in global searches for 'Hussar jacket' in October 2025 reflects a growing cultural and consumer interest in the style, positioning it as a key fashion trend for the fall season.
title: Look of the Week: From Jimi Hendrix to Jodie Turner-Smith, why fashion loves a military jacket
